cRefPattern.p: This pointer pattern extracts act, scene, and line.
This pointer pattern extracts act and scene.

castItem.roleDesc: his brother, the usurping Duke of Milan
son to the King of Naples

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: On a ship at sea: a tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.
Enter a Ship-Master and a Boatswain.

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p: Boatswain!

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: Here, master: what cheer?

sp.speaker: Mast.
sp.p:
Good, speak to the mariners: fall
to't,
yarely, or we run ourselves aground:
bestir, bestir. Exit.
Enter Mariners.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p:
Heigh, my hearts! cheerly, cheerly,
my hearts!
yare, yare! Take in the topsail.
Tend to the master's
whistle. Blow, till thou
burst thy wind, if room
enough!
Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, FERDINAND,
GONZALO, and others.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p:
Good boatswain, have care. Where's
the master?
Play the men.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: I pray now, keep below.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where is the master, boatswain?

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p:
Do you not hear him? You mar
our labour:
keep your cabins: you do assist
the storm.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Nay, good, be patient.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p:
When the sea is. Hence! What
cares these roarers
for the name of king? To
cabin: silence! trouble
us not.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p:
None that I more love than myself.
You are
a counsellor; if you can command
these elements to silence,
and work the peace
of the present, we will not
hand a rope more;
use your authority: if you cannot,
give thanks
you have lived so long, and make
yourself
ready in your cabin for the mischance of the
hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good hearts! Out
of our
way, I say. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
I have great comfort from this fellow:
methinks
he hath no drowning mark
upon him; his complexion
is perfect gallows.
Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging:
make
the rope of his destiny our cable, for our
own
doth little advantage. If he be not born to be
hanged, our case is miserable. [Exeunt
Re-enter Boatswain.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p:
Down with the topmast! yare!
lower, lower!
Bring her to try with main-course.
[A cry within.] A plague
upon
this howling! they are louder than the weather
or
our office. Re-enter SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, and GONZALO.
Yet again! what do you here? Shall we
give o'er and drown? Have you a mind to sink?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
A pox o' your throat, you bawling,
blasphemous,
incharitable dog!

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: Work you then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Hang, cur! hang, you whoreson, insolent
noisemaker!
We are less afraid to be
drowned than thou art.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
I'll warrant him for drowning;
though the
ship were no stronger than a nutshell
and as leaky as
an unstaunched wench.

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p:
Lay her a-hold, a-hold! set her two
courses off
to sea again; lay her off.
Enter Mariners wet.

sp.speaker: Mariners.
sp.p:
All lost! to prayers, to prayers!
all lost!

sp.speaker: Boats.
sp.p: What, must our mouths be cold?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: The king and prince at prayers! let's assist them.
For our case is as theirs.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'm out of patience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:
This wide-chapp'd rascal--would thou mightst lie drowning
The washing of ten tides!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: He'll be hang'd yet,
Though every drop of water swear against it

And gape at widest to glut him. [A confused noise within:
'Mercy on us!'--
'We split, we split!'--'Farewell my wife and children!'--
'Farewell, brother'--'We split, we split, we split!']

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let's all sink with the king.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Let's take leave of him. [Exeunt Ant. and Seb.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Now would I give a thousand furlongs
of sea
for an acre of barren ground,
long heath, brown
furze, any thing. The
wills above be done! but I would
fain die a dry
death. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If by your art, my dearest father, you have
Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch,
But that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheek.
Dashes the fire out. O, I have suffer'd
With those that I saw suffer: a brave vessel,
Who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her,
Dash'd all to pieces. O, the cry did knock
Against my very heart. Poor souls, they perish'd.
Had I been any god of power, I would
Have sunk the sea within the earth or ere
It should the good ship so have swallow'd and
The fraughting souls within her.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Be collected:
No more amazement: tell your piteous heart
There's no harm done.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O, woe the day!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: No harm.
I have done nothing but in care of thee,
Of thee, my dear one, thee, my daughter, who
Art ignorant of what thou art, nought knowing
Of whence I am, nor that I am more better
Than Prospero, master of a full poor cell,
And thy no greater father.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: More to know
Did never meddle with my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: 'Tis time
I should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand,
And pluck my magic garment from me. So: [Lays down his mantle.
Lie there, my art. Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort.
The direful spectacle of the wreck, which touch'd
The very virtue of compassion in thee,
I have with such provision in mine art
So safely ordered that there is no soul-
No, not so much perdition as an hair
Betid to any creature in the vessel
Which thou heard'st cry, which thou saw'st sink. Sit down;
For thou must now know farther.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You have often
Begun to tell me what I am, but stopp'd
And left me to a bootless inquisition,
Concluding 'Stay: not yet.'

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: The hour's now come;
The very minute bids thee ope thine ear;
Obey and be attentive. Canst thou remember
A time before we came unto this cell?
I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not
Out three years old.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Certainly, sir, I can.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: By what? by any other house or person?
Of any thing the image tell me that
Hath kept with thy remembrance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis far off
And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it
That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysm of time?
If thou remember'st aught ere thou camest here,
How thou camest here thou mayst.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But that I do not.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since,
Thy father was the Duke of Milan and
A prince of power.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, are not you my father?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and
She said thou wast my daughter; and thy father
Was Duke of Milan; and thou his only heir
And princess no worse issued.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O the heavens!
What foul play had we, that we came from thence?
Or blessed was't we did?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Both, both, my girl:
By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heaved thence,
But blessedly holp hither.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O, my heart bleeds
To think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to,
Which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: My brother and thy uncle, call'd Antonio--
I pray thee, mark me--that a brother should
Be so perfidious!--he whom next thyself
Of all the world I loved and to him put
The manage of my state; as at that time
Through all the signories it was the first
And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed
In dignity, and for the liberal arts
Without a parallel; those being all my study,
The government I cast upon my brother
And to my state grew stranger, being transported
And rapt in secret studies. Thy false uncle--
Dost thou attend me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, most heedfully.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Being once perfected how to grant suits,
How to deny them, who to advance and who
To trash for over-topping, new created
The creatures that were mine, I say, or changed 'em,
Or else new form'd 'em; having both the key
Of officer and office, set all hearts i' the state
To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was
The ivy which had hid my princely trunk,
And suck'd my verdure out on 't. Thou attend'st not.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O, good sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: I pray thee, mark me.
I, thus neglecting worldly ends, and dedicated
To closeness and the bettering of my mind
With that which, but by being so retired,
O'er-prized all popular rate, in my false brother
Awaked an evil nature; and my trust,
Like a good parent, did beget of him
A falsehood in its contrary as great
As my trust was; which had indeed no limit,
A confidence sans bound. He being thus lorded,
Not only with what my revenue yielded,
But what my power might else exact, like one
Who having into truth, by telling of it,
Made such a sinner of his memory,
To credit his own lie, he did believe
He was indeed the duke; out o' the substitution,
And executing the outward face of royalty,
With all prerogative: hence his ambition growing--
Dost thou hear?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: To have no screen between this part he play'd
And him he play'd it for, he needs will be
Absolute Milan. Me, poor man, my library
Was dukedom large enough: of temporal royalties
He thinks me now incapable; confederates--
So dry he was for sway--wi' the King of Naples
To give him annual tribute, do him homage,
Subject his coronet to his crown and bend
The dukedom yet unbow'd--alas, poor Milan!--
To most ignoble stooping.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O the heavens!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Mark his condition and the event; then tell me
If this might be a brother.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I should sin
To think but nobly of my grandmother:
Good wombs have borne bad sons.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Now the condition.
This King of Naples, being an enemy
To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit;
Which was, that he, in lieu o' the premises
Of homage and I know not how much tribute,
Should presently extirpate me and mine
Out of the dukedom and confer fair Milan
With all the honours on my brother: whereon,
A treacherous army levied, one midnight
Fated to the purpose did Antonio open
The gates of Milan, and, i' the dead of darkness,
The ministers for the purpose hurried thence
Me and thy crying self.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alack, for pity!
I, not remembering how I cried out then,
Will cry it o'er again: it is a hint
That wrings mine eyes to 't.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Hear a little further
And then I'll bring thee to the present business
Which now 's upon 's; without the which this story
Were most impertinent.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Wherefore did they not
That hour destroy us?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Well demanded, wench:
My tale provokes that question. Dear, they durst not,
So dear the love my people bore me, nor set
A mark so bloody on the business, but
With colours fairer painted their foul ends.
In few, they hurried us aboard a bark,
Bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepared
A rotten carcass of a boat, not rigg'd,
Nor tackle, sail, nor mast; the very rats
Instinctively have quit it: there they hoist us,
To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sigh
To the winds whose pity, sighing back again,
Did us but loving wrong.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alack, what trouble
Was I then to you!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: O, a cherubin
Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile,
Infused with a fortitude from heaven,
When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt,
Under my burthen groan'd; which raised in me
An undergoing stomach, to bear up
Against what should ensue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How came we ashore?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: By Providence divine.
Some food we had and some fresh water that
A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo,
Out of his charity, who being then appointed
Master of this design, did give us, with
Rich garments, linens, stuffs and necessaries,
Which since have steaded much; so, of his gentleness,
Knowing I loved my books, he furnish'd me
From mine own library with volumes that
I prize above my dukedom.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Would I might
But ever see that man!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Now I arise: [Resumes his mantle.
Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow.
Here in this island we arrived; and here
Have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit
Than other princesses can that have more time
For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Heavens thank you for 't! And now, I pray you, sir,
For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reason
For raising this sea-storm?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Know thus far forth.
By accident most strange, bountiful Fortune,
Now my dear lady, hath mine enemies
Brought to this shore; and by my prescience
I find my zenith doth depend upon
A most auspicious star, whose influence
If now I court not but omit, my fortunes
Will ever after droop. Here cease more questions:
Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness,
And give it way: I know thou canst not choose. [Miranda sleeps.
Come away, servant, come. I am ready now.
Approach, my Ariel, come. Enter ARIEL.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: All hail, great master! grave sir, hail! I come
To answer thy best pleasure; be 't to fly,
To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride
On the curl'd clouds, to thy strong bidding task
Ariel and all his quality.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Hast thou, spirit,
Perform'd to point the tempest that I bade thee?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: To every article.
I boarded the king's ship; now on the beak,
Now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin,
I flamed amazement: sometimes I'ld divide,
And burn in many places; on the topmast,
The yards and bowsprit, would I flame distinctly,
Then meet and join. Jove's lightnings, the precursors
O' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentary
And sight-outrunning were not; the fire and cracks
Of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune
Seem to besiege and make his bold waves tremble,
Yea, his dread trident shake.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: My brave spirit!
Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil
Would not infect his reason?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Not a soul
But felt a fever of the mad and play'd
Some tricks of desperation. All but mariners
Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel,
Then all afire with me: the king's son, Ferdinand,
With hair up-staring,--then like reeds, not hair,--
Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty,
And all the devils are here.'

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Why, that's my spirit!
But was not this nigh shore?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Close by, my master,

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: But are they, Ariel, safe?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Not a hair perish'd;
On their sustaining garments not a blemish,
But fresher than before: and, as thou badest me,
In troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
The king's son have I landed by himself;
Whom I left cooling of the air with sighs
In an odd angle of the isle and sitting,
His arms in this sad knot.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Of the king's ship
The mariners say how thou hast disposed
And all the rest o' the fleet.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Safely in harbour
Is the king's ship; in the deep nook, where once
Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew
From the still-vex'd Bermoothes, there she's hid:
The mariners all under hatches stow'd;
Who, with a charm join'd to their suffer'd labour,
I have left asleep: and for the rest o' the fleet
Which I dispersed, they all have met again
And are upon the Mediterranean flote,
Bound sadly home for Naples,
Supposing that they saw the king's ship wreck'd
And his great person perish.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Ariel, thy charge
Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work.
What is the time o' the day?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Past the mid season.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: At least two glasses. The time 'twixt six and now
Must by us both be spent most preciously.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains,
Let me remember thee what thou hast promised
Which is not yet perform'd me.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: How now? moody?
What is't thou canst demand?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: My liberty.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Before the time be out? no more!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I prithee,
Remember I have done thee worthy service;
Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served
Without or grudge or grumblings: thou didst promise
To bate me a full year.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Dost thou forget
From what a torment I did free thee?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the ooze
Of the salt deep,
To run upon the sharp wind of the north,
To do me business in the veins o' the earth
When it is baked with frost.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I do not, sir.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot
The foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy
Was grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Sir, in Argier.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: O, was she so? I must
Once in a month recount what thou hast been,
Which thou forget'st. This damn'd witch Sycorax,
For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible
To enter human hearing, from Argier,
Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did
They would not take her life. Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child
And there was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave,
As thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant;
And, for thou wast a spirit too delicate
To act her earthly and abhorr'd commands,
Refusing her grand hests, she did confine thee,
By help of her more potent ministers
And in her most unmitigable rage,
Into a cloven pine; within which rift
Imprison'd thou didst painfully remain
A dozen years; within which space she died
And left thee there; where thou didst vent thy groans
As fast as mill-wheels strike. Then was this island--
Save for the son that she did litter here,
A freckled whelp hag-born--not honour'd with
A human shape.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Yes, Caliban her son.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Dull thing, I say so; he, that Caliban
Whom now I keep in service. Thou best know'st
What torment I did find thee in; thy groans
Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts
Of ever angry bears: it was a torment
To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax
Could not again undo: it was mine art,
When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape
The pine and let thee out.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: I thank thee, master.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak
And peg thee in his knotty entrails till
Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Pardon, master;
I will be correspondent to command
And do my spiriting gently.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Do so, and after two days
I will discharge thee.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: That's my noble master!
What shall I do? say what; what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject
To no sight but thine and mine, invisible
To every eyeball else. Go take this shape
And hither come in 't: go, hence with diligence! [Exit Ariel.
Awake, dear heart, awake! thou hast slept well,
Awake!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The strangeness of your story put
Heaviness in me.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Shake it off. Come on;
We'll visit Caliban my slave, who never
Yields us kind answer.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis a villain, sir,
I do not love to look on.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: But, as 'tis,
We cannot miss him: he does make our fire,
Fetch in our wood and serves in offices
That profit us. What, ho! slave! Caliban!
Thou earth, thou! speak.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: There's wood enough within.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Come forth, I say! there's other business for thee:
Come, thou tortoise! when? Re-enter ARIEL like a water-nymph.
Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel,
Hark in thine ear.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: My lord, it shall be done. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself
Upon thy wicked dam, come forth! Enter CALIBAN.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: As wicked dew as e'er my mother brush'd
With raven's feather from unwholesome fen
Drop on you both! a south-west blow on ye
And blister you all o'er!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps,
Side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchins
Shall, for that vast of night that they may work,
All exercise on thee; thou shalt be pinch'd
As thick as honeycomb, each pinch more stinging
Than bees that made 'em.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I must eat my dinner.
This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother,
Which thou takest from me. When thou camest first,
Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give me
Water with berries in 't, and teach me how
To name the bigger light, and how the less,
That burn by day and night: and then I loved thee
And show'd thee all the qualities o' the isle,
The fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile:
Cursed be I that did so! All the charms
Of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you!
For I am all the subjects that you have,
Which first was mine own king: and here you sty me
In this hard rock, whiles you do keep from me
The rest o' the island.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou most lying slave,
Whom stripes may move, not kindness! I have used thee,
Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee
In mine own cell, till thou didst seek to violate
The honour of my child.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O ho, O ho! would 't had been done!
Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else
This isle with Calibans.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Abhorred slave,
Which any print of goodness wilt not take,
Being capable of all ill! I pitied thee,
Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour
One thing or other: when thou didst not, savage,
Know thine own meaning, but wouldst gabble like
A thing most brutish, I endow'd thy purposes
With words that made them known. But thy vile race,
Though thou didst learn, had that in 't which good natures
Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou
Deservedly confined into this rock
Who hadst deserved more than a prison.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You taught me language; and my profit on 't
Is, I know how to curse. The red plague rid you
For learning me your language!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Hag-seed, hence!
Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou 'rt best,
To answer other business. Shrug'st thou,malice?
If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly
What I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps,
Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar
That beasts shall tremble at thy din.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l:
No, pray thee.
[Aside]
I must obey: his art is of such power,
It would control my dam's god, Setebos,
And make a vassal of him.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l:
So, slave; hence! [Exit Caliban. Re-enter ARIEL, invisible, playing and singing; FERDINAND following.
ARIEL'S song.
Come unto these yellow sands.
And then take hands: Courtsied when you have and kiss'd
The wild waves whist, Foot it featly here and there;
And, sweet sprites, the burthen bear. Burthen [dispersedly]
. Hark, hark!
Bow-wow.
The watch-dogs bark:
Bow-wow.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Hark, hark! I hear
The strain of strutting chanticleer
Cry, Cock-a-diddle-dow.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth?
It sounds no more: and, sure it waits upon
Some god o' the island. Sitting on a bank,
Weeping again the king my father's wreck,
This music crept by me upon the waters,
Allaying both their fury and my passion
With its sweet air: thence I have follow'd it,
Or it hath drawn me rather. But 'tis gone,
No, it begins again. ARIEL sings.

lg.l: Full fathom five thy father lies;
Of his bones are coral made;
Those are pearls that were his eyes:
Nothing of him that doth fade
But doth suffer a sea-change
Into something rich and strange.
Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell: Burthen.
Ding-dong.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Hark! now I hear them,--Dingdong, bell.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The ditty does remember my drown'd father.
This is no mortal business, nor no sound
That the earth owes. I hear it now above me.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: The fringed curtains of thine eye advance
And say what thou seest yond.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What is 't? a spirit?
Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir,
it carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such senses
As we have, such. This gallant which thou seest
Was in the wreck; and, but he 's something stain'd
With grief that 's beauty's canker, thou mightst call him
A goodly person: he hath lost his fellows
And strays about to find 'em.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I might call him
A thing divine, for nothing natural
I ever saw so noble.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: It goes on, I see,
As my soul prompts it. Spirit, fine spirit! I'll free thee
Within two days for this.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Most sure, the goddess
On whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayer
May know if you remain upon this island;
And that you will some good instruction give
How I may bear me here: my prime request,
Which I do last pronounce, is, O you wonder!
If you be maid or no?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No wonder, sir;
But certainly a maid.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My language! heavens!
I am the best of them that speak this speech,
Were I but where 'tis spoken.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: How? the best?
What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders
To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me:
And that he does I weep: myself am Naples,
Who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld
The king my father wreck'd.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alack, for mercy!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, faith, and all his lords; the Duke of Milan
And his brave son being twain.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: The Duke of Milan
And his more braver daughter could control thee,
If now 'twere fit to do't. At the first sight
They have changed eyes. Delicate Ariel,
I'll set thee free for this. [To Fer.] A word, good sir;
I fear you have done yourself some wrong: a word.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why speaks my father so ungently? This
Is the third man that e'er I saw, the first
That e'er I sigh'd for: pity move my father
To be inclined my way

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O, if a virgin,
And your affection not gone forth, I'll make you
The queen of Naples.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l:
Soft, sir! one word more.
[Aside]
They are both in either's powers; but this swift business
I must uneasy make, lest too light winning
Make the prize light. [To Fer.] One word more; I charge thee
That thou attend me: thou dost here usurp
The name thou owest not; and hast put thyself
Upon this island as a spy, to win it
From me, the lord on't.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, as I am a man,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: There's nothing ill can dwell in such a temple:
If the ill spirit have so fair a house,
Good things will strive to dwell with't.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Follow me.
Speak not you for him; he 's a traitor. Come;
I'll manacle thy neck and feet together:
Sea-water shalt thou drink; thy food shall be
The fresh-brook muscles, wither'd roots and husks
Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No;
I will resist such entertainment till

Mine enemy has more power.
[Draws, and is charmed from moving.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O dear father,
Make not too rash a trial of him, for
He's gentle and not fearful.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: What? I say,
My foot my tutor? Put thy sword up, traitor;
Who makest a show but darest not strike, thy conscience
Is so possess'd with guilt: come from thy ward.
For I can here disarm thee with this stick
And make thy weapon drop.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Beseech you, father.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Hence! hang not on my garments.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, have pity;
I'll be his surety.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Silence! one word more
Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee. What!
An advocate for an impostor! hush!
Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he,
Having seen but him and Caliban: foolish wench!
To the most of men this is a Caliban
And they to him are angels.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My affections
Are then most humble; I have no ambition
To see a goodlier man.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Come on; obey:
Thy nerves are in their infancy again
And have no vigour in them.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So they are;
My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up.
My father's loss, the weakness which I feel,
The wreck of all my friends, nor this man's threats,
To whom I am subdued, are but light to me,
Might I but through my prison once a day
Behold this maid: all corners else o' the earth
Let liberty make use of; space enough
Have I in such a prison.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l:
It works. [To Fer.]
Come on.
Thou hast done well, fine Ariel! To Fer.

Follow me.
[To Ari.]
Hark what thou else shalt do me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Be of comfort;
My father's of a better nature, sir,
Than he appears by speech: this is unwonted
Which now came from him.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou shalt be as free
As mountain winds: but then exactly do
All points of my command.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: To the syllable.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Come, follow. Speak not for him. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage:
Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO, ADRIAN,
FRANCISCO, and others.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Beseech you, sir, be merry; you have cause,
So have we all, of joy; for our escape
Is much beyond our loss. Our hint of woe
Is common; every day some sailor's wife,
The masters of some merchant and the merchant
Have just our theme of woe; but for the miracle,
I mean our preservation, few in millions
Can speak like us: then wisely, good sir, weigh
Our sorrow with our comfort,

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Prithee, peace.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: He receives comfort like cold porridge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The visitor will not give him o'er so.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
Look, he 's winding up the watch of
his wit; by and by it will strike.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Sir,--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: One: tell.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd,
Comes to the entertainer--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: A dollar.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Dolour comes to him, indeed: you
have spoken
truer than you purposed.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
You have taken it wiselier than I
meant you
should.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Therefore, my lord,--

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I prithee, spare.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Well, I have done: but yet,--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: He will be talking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Which, of he or Adrian, for a good
wager,
first begins to crow?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: The old cock.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The cockerel.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Done. The wager?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A laughter.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: A match!

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Though this island seem to be desert,--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha!
So, you're paid.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p:
Uninhabitable and almost
inaccessible,--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Yet,--

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Yet,--

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He could not miss 't.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p:
It must needs be of subtle, tender
and delicate
temperance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Temperance was a delicate wench.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
Ay, and a subtle; as he most learnedly
delivered.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: As if it had lungs and rotten ones.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Here is every thing advantageous to life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: True; save means to live.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Of that there's none, or little.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
How lush and lusty the grass looks!
how green!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The ground indeed is tawny.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: With an eye of green in't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He misses not much.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
No; he doth but mistake the truth
totally.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
But the rarity of it is,--which is indeed
almost
beyond credit,--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: As many vouched rarities are.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
That our garments, being, as they
were, drenched
in the sea, hold notwithstanding
their freshness and
glosses, being rather
new-dyed than stained with salt
water.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
If but one of his pockets could
speak, would
it not say he lies?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
Ay, or very falsely pocket up his
report.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Methinks our garments are now as
fresh as
when we put them on first in Afric,
at the marriage
of the king's fair daughter
Claribel to the King of Tunis.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
'Twas a sweet marriage, and we
prosper well in
our return.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p:
Tunis was never graced before with
such a paragon
to their queen.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Not since widow Dido's time.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Widow! a pox o' that! How came
that widow
in? widow Dido!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
What if he had said 'widower
AEneas' too?
Good Lord, how you take it!

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p:
'Widow Dido' said you? you make
me study
of that: she was of Carthage, not of
Tunis.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.p: Carthage?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: I assure you, Carthage.

sp.speaker: Seb.
Ant.
sp.p:
What impossible matter will he
make easy next?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
I think he will carry this island home
in his
pocket and give it his son for an
apple.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
And, sowing the kernels of it in the
sea, bring
forth more islands.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, in good time.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Sir, we were talking that our garments
seem
now as fresh as when we were at
Tunis at the marriage
of your daughter, who
is now queen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And the rarest that e'er came there.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O, widow Dido! ay, widow Dido.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as
the first day I
wore it? I mean, in a sort.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That sort was well fished for.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p: When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You cram these words into mine ears against
The stomach of my sense. Would I had never
Married my daughter there! for, coming thence,
My son is lost and, in my rate, she too,
Who is so far from Italy removed
I ne'er again shall see her. O thou mine heir
Of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish
Hath made his meal on thee?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Sir, he may live:
I saw him beat the surges under him,
And ride upon their backs; he trod the water,
Whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted
The surge most swoln that met him; his bold head
'Bove the contentious waves he kept, and oar'd
Himself with his good arms in lusty stroke
To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd,
As stooping to relieve him: I not doubt
He came alive to land.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: No, no, he's gone.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss,
That would not bless our Europe with your daughter,
But rather lose her to an African;
Where she at least is banish'd from your eye,
Who hath cause to wet the grief on 't.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Prithee, peace.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: You were kneel'd to and importuned otherwise
By all of us, and the fair soul herself
Weigh'd between loathness and obedience, at
Which end o' the beam should bow. We have lost your son,
I fear, for ever: Milan and Naples have
Moe widows in them of this business' making
Than we bring men to comfort them:
The fault 's your own.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: So is the dear'st o' the loss.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My lord Sebastian,
The truth you speak doth lack some gentleness
And time to speak it in: you rub the sore,
When you should bring the plaster.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And most chirurgeonly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: It is foul weather in us all, good sir,
When you are cloudy.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Foul weather?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Very foul.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord,--

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He'ld sow 't with nettle-seed.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Or docks, or mallows.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: And were the king on 't, what would I do?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: 'Scape being drunk for want of wine.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I' the commonwealth I would by contraries
Execute all things; for no kind of traffic
Would I admit; no name of magistrate;
Letters should not be known; riches, poverty.
And use of service, none; contract, succession,
Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none;
No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil;
No occupation; all men idle, all;
And women too, but innocent and pure;
No sovereignty;--

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Yet he would be king on 't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
The latter end of his commonwealth
forgets
the beginning.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: All things in common nature should produce
Without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony,
Sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine,
Would I not have; but nature should bring forth,
Of it own kind, all foison, all abundance,
To feed my innocent people.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No marrying 'mong his subjects?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: None, man; all idle: whores and knaves.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I would with such perfection govern, sir,
To excel the golden age.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: God save his majesty!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Long live Gonzalo!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: And,--do you mark me, sir?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p:
Prithee, no more: thou dost talk
nothing to me.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
I do well believe your highness; and
did it
to minister occasion to these gentlemen,
who are of
such sensible and nimble lungs
that they always use
to laugh at nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas you we laughed at.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Who in this kind of merry fooling
am nothing
to you: so you may continue and
laugh at nothing still.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a blow was there given!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: An it had not fallen flat-long.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
You are gentlemen of brave mettle;
you would
lift the moon out of her sphere, if
she would continue
in it five weeks without
changing.
Enter ARIEL, invisible, playing solemn music.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
We would so, and then go a
batfowling.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, good my lord, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
No, I warrant you; I will not adventure
my
discretion so weakly. Will you
laugh me asleep, for I
am very heavy?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Go sleep, and hear us.
All sleep except Alon., Seb., and Ant.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What, all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyes

Would with themselves, shut up my thoughts:
I find
They are inclined to do so.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Please you, sir.
Do not omit the heavy offer of it:
It seldom visits sorrow; when it doth,
It is a comforter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We two, my lord,

Will guard your person
while you take your rest,
And watch your safety.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l:
Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
Alonso sleeps. Exit Ariel.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What a strange drowsiness possesses them!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is the quality o' the climate.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why

Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find
not
Myself disposed to sleep.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nor I; my spirits are nimble.
They fell together all, as by consent;
They dropp'd, as by a thunder-stroke. What might,
Worthy Sebastian? O, what might?--No more:--
And yet methinks I see it in thy face,
What thou shouldst be: the occasion speaks thee, and
My strong imagination sees a crown
Dropping upon thy head.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What, art thou waking?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do you not hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I do; and surely
It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st
Out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say?
This is a strange repose, to be asleep
With eyes wide open; standing, speaking moving,
And yet so fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Noble Sebastian,
Thou let'st thy fortune sleep--die, rather; wink'st
Whiles thou art waking.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou dost snore distinctly;
There's meaning in thy snores.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am more serious than my custom: you
Must be so too, if heed me; which to do
Trebles thee o'er.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Well, I am standing water.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll teach you how to flow.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do so: to ebb
Hereditary sloth instructs me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O,
If you but knew how you the purpose cherish
Whiles thus you mock it! how, in stripping it,
You more invest it! Ebbing men, indeed,
Most often do so near the bottom run
By their own fear or sloth.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Prithee, say on;
The setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim
A matter from thee, and a birth indeed
Which throes thee much to yield.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus, sir:
Although this lord of weak remembrance, this,
Who shall be of as little memory
When he is earth'd, hath here almost persuaded,--
For he's a spirit of persuasion, only
Professes to persuade,--the king his son's alive,
'Tis as impossible that he's undrown'd
As he that sleeps here swims.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I have no hope
That he's undrown'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, out of that 'no hope'
What great hope have you! no hope that way is
Another way so high a hope that even
Ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond,
But doubt discovery there. Will you grant with me
That Ferdinand is drown'd?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then, tell me,
Who's the next heir of Naples?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Claribel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She that is queen of Tunis; she that dwells
Ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples
Can have no note, unless the sun were post--
The man i' the moon's too slow--till newborn chins
Be rough and razorable; she that--from whom?
We all were sea-swallow'd, though some cast again,
And by that destiny to perform an act
Whereof what's past is prologue, what to come
In yours and my discharge.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What stuff is this! how say you?
'Tis true, my brother's daughter's queen of Tunis;
So is she heir of Naples: 'twixt which regions
There is some space.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A space whose every cubit
Seems to cry out, 'How shall that Claribel
Measure us back to Naples? Keep in Tunis,
And let Sebastian wake.' Say, this were death
That now hath seized them; why, they were no worse
Than now they are. There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that sleeps; lords that can prate
As amply and unnecessarily
As this Gonzalo; I myself could make
A chough of as deep chat. O, that you bore
The mind that I do! what a sleep were this
For your advancement Do you understand me?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Methinks I do.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And how does your content
Tender your own good fortune?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I remember
You did supplant your brother Prospero.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: True:
And look how well my garments sit upon me;
Much feater than before: my brother's servants
Were then my fellows; now they are my men.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But, for your conscience?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ay, sir; where lies that? if 'twere a kibe,
'Twould put me to my slipper: but I feel not
This deity in my bosom: twenty consciences,
That stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they
And melt ere they molest! Here lies your brother,
No better than the earth he lies upon,
If he were that which now he's like, that's dead;
Whom I, with this obedient steel, three inches of it,
Can lay to bed for ever; whiles you, doing thus,
To the perpetual wink for aye might put
This ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who
Should not upbraid our course. For all the rest,
They'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk;
They'll tell the clock to any business that
We say befits the hour.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thy case, dear friend,
Shall be my precedent; as thou got'st Milan,
I'll come by Naples. Draw thy sword: one stroke
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou payest;
And I the king shall love thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Draw together;
And when I rear my hand, do you the like,
To fall it on Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l:
O, but one word. [They talk apart.]
Re-enter ARIEL, invisible.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: My master through his art foresees the danger
That you, his friend, are in; and sends me forth--

For else his project dies--to keep them living,
[Sings in Gonzalo's ear.

lg.l: While you here do snoring lie,
Open-eyed conspiracy
His time doth take.
If of life you keep a care,
Shake off slumber, and beware:
Awake, awake!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then let us both be sudden.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Now, good angels
Preserve the king. [They wake.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Why, how now? ho, awake! Why are you drawn?
Wherefore this ghastly looking?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Whiles we stood here securing your repose,
Even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing
Like bulls, or rather lions: did 't not wake you?
It struck mine ear most terribly.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I heard nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, 'twas a din to fright a monster's ear,
To make an earthquake! sure, it was the roar
Of a whole herd of lions.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Heard you this, Gonzalo?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Upon mine honour, sir, I heard a humming,
And that a strange one too, which did awake me:
I shaked you, sir, and cried: as mine eyes open'd,
I saw their weapons drawn: there was a noise,
That's verily. 'Tis best we stand upon our guard,
Or that we quit this place: let's draw our weapons.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Lead off this ground; and let's make further search
For my poor son.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Heavens keep him from these beasts!
For he is, sure, i' the island.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Lead away.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Prospero my lord shall know what I have done:
So, king, go safely on to seek thy son. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: Enter CALIBAN with a burden of food.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: All the infections that the sun sucks up
From bogs, fens, flats, on Prosper fall and make him
By inch-meal a disease! His spirits hear me
And yet I needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch,
Fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' the mire,
Nor lead me, like a firebrand, in the dark
Out of my way, unless he bid 'em; but
For every trifle are they set upon me;
Sometime like apes that mow and chatter at me.
And after bite me, then like hedgehogs which
Lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount
Their pricks at my footfall; sometime am I
All wound with adders who with cloven tongues

Do hiss me into madness.
Enter TRINCULO.
Lo, now, lo!
Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me
For bringing wood in slowly. I'll fall flat;
Perchance he will not mind me.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Here's neither bush nor shrub, to
bear off any
weather at all, and another storm
brewing; I hear it
sing i' the wind: yond same
black cloud, yond huge
one, looks like a foul
bombard that would shed his
liquor. If it
should thunder as it did before, I know
not
where to hide my head: yond same cloud cannot
choose but fall by pailfuls. What have we
here? a man
or a fish? dead or alive? A fish:
he smells like a fish; a
very ancient and fish-like
smell; a kind of not of the
newest Poor-John.
A strange fish! Were I in England
now,
as once I was, and had but this fish painted,
not
a holiday fool there but would give a piece
of silver:
there would this monster make a man:
any strange
beast there makes a man: when
they will not give a
doit to relieve a lame
beggar, they will lay out ten to see
a dead Indian.
Legged like a man! and his fins like
arms! Warm o' my troth! I do now let loose
my opinions;
hold it no longer: this is no fish,
but an islander,
that hath lately suffered by a
thunderbolt. [Thunder.] Alas,
the storm is
come again! my best way is to creep under
his gaberdine; there is no other shelter hereabouts:
misery acquaints a man with strange
bed-fellows.
I will here shroud till the dregs of
the storm
be past.
Enter STEPHANO, singing: a bottle in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ste.

lg.l: I shall no more to sea, to sea,
Here shall I die ashore--

sp.p:
This is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's
funeral: well, here's my comfort. [Drinks.
[Sings.

lg.l: The master, the swabber, the boatswain and I,
The gunner and his mate
Loved Mall, Meg and Marian and Margery,
But none of us cared for Kate;
For she had a tongue with a tang,
Would cry to a sailor, Go hang!
She loved not the savour of tar nor of pitch,
Yet a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch:
Then to sea, boys, and let her go hang!

sp.l:
This is a scurvy tune too:
but here's my comfort. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Do not torment me: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
What's the matter?
Have we devils
here?
Do you put tricks upon 's with savages
and men of
Ind, ha? I have not 'scaped drowning
to be afeard
now of your four legs; for
it hath been said, As proper
a man as ever
went on four legs cannot make him
give
ground; and it shall be said so again while
Stephano
breathes at's nostrils.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: The spirit torments me; Oh!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
This is some monster of the isle with
four legs,
who hath got, as I take it, an ague.
Where the devil
should he learn our language?
I will give him some relief,
if it be but for
that. If I can recover him and keep him tame
and get to Naples with him, he's a present
for
any emperor that ever trod on
neat's-leather.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Do not torment me, prithee; I'll bring
my
wood home faster.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
He's in his fit now and does not talk
after the
wisest. He shall taste of my bottle:
if he have never
drunk wine afore, it will go
near to remove his fit.
If I can recover him
and keep him tame, I will not take
too much
for him; he shall pay for him that hath him,
and that soundly.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Thou dost me yet but little hurt; thou
wilt anon,
I know it by thy trembling: now
Prosper works
upon thee.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Come on your ways; open your
mouth; here
is that which will give language
to you, cat: open your
mouth; this will shake
your shaking, I can tell you, and
that soundly:
you cannot tell who's your friend: open
your
chaps again.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
I should know that voice:
it should
be--
but he is drowned; and these are devils:
O defend
me!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Four legs and two voices: a most delicate
monster! His forward voice now is to
speak well of
his friend; his backward voice
is to utter foul speeches
and to detract. If all
the wine in my bottle will recover
him, I will
help his ague. Come. Amen! I will
pour some
in thy other mouth.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: Stephano!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Doth thy other mouth call me?
Mercy, mercy!
This is a devil, and no monster:
I will leave him; I
have no long spoon.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Stephano! If thou beest Stephano,
touch me and
speak to me; for I am Trinculo
--be not afeard--thy
good friend Trinculo.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
If thou beest Trinculo, come forth: I'll
pull
thee by the lesser legs: if any be Trinculo's
legs,
these are they. Thou art very
Trinculo indeed! How
camest thou to be the
siege of this moon-calf? can
he vent Trinculos?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
I took him to be killed with a thunder-stroke.
But
art thou not drowned, Stephano?
I hope now thou art
not drowned. Is
the storm overblown? I hid me
under the
dead moon-calf's gaberdine for fear of
the
storm. And art thou living, Stephano? O
Stephano,
two Neapolitans 'scaped!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Prithee, do not turn me about; my
stomach
is not constant.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
These be fine things, an if they be not sprites.
That's a brave god and bears celestial liquor.
I will
kneel to him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
How didst thou 'scape?
How camest
thou hither?
swear by this bottle how thou
camest hither. I escaped
upon a butt of sack
which the sailors heaved o'erboard,
by this
bottle! which I made of the bark of
a tree
with mine own hands since I was cast
ashore.

sp.speaker: Cal.
Ste.
sp.p: Here; swear then how thou escapedst.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Swum ashore, man, like a duck: I
can swim
like a duck, I'll be sworn.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Here, kiss the book,
Though thou
canst swim like a duck, thou art made
like a
goose.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: O Stephano, hast any more of this?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
The whole butt, man: my cellar is in
a rock
by the sea-side where my wine is hid.
How now, moon-calf! how does thine ague?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Hast thou not dropp'd from heaven?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Out o' the moon, I do assure thee:
I was the
man i' the moon when time was.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I have seen thee in her and I do adore thee:
My mistress show'd me thee and thy dog and thy bush.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Come, swear to that; kiss the book:
I will
furnish it anon with new contents:
swear.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
By this good light, this is a very
shallow monster!
I afeard of him! A very
weak monster!
The man i' the moon!
A
most poor credulous monster!
Well drawn,
monster, in good sooth!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'll show thee every fertile inch o' th' island;

And
I will kiss thy foot: I prithee, be my god.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
By this light, a most perfidious and
drunken
monster! when 's god's asleep, he'll
rob his bottle.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'll kiss thy foot; I'll swear myself thy subject.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Come on then; down, and swear.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
I shall laugh myself to death at this
puppy-headed
monster. A most scurvy monster!
I could find in
my heart to beat him,--

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Come, kiss.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
But that the poor monster's in
drink:
an abominable monster!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l:
I'll show thee the best springs; I'll pluck thee
berries;
I'll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
A plague upon the tyrant that I serve!
I'll bear him no more sticks, but follow thee,

Thou
wondrous man.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
A most ridiculous monster, to make
a wonder of
a poor drunkard!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow;
And I with my long nails will dig thee pignuts;
Show thee a jay's nest and instruct thee how

To snare
the nimble marmoset; I'll bring thee

To clustering
filberts and sometimes I'll get thee

Young scamels
from the rock. Wilt thou go with me?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
I prithee now, lead the way without
any more
talking. Trinculo, the king and all
our company else
being drowned, we will inherit
here: here; bear my
bottle: fellow
Trinculo, we'll fill him by and by
again.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Farewell, master; farewell, farewell!

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
A howling monster; a drunken
monster!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l:
No more dams I'll make for fish;
Nor fetch in firing
At requiring;
Nor scrape trencher, nor wash dish:
'Ban, 'Ban, Cacaliban
Has a new master: get a new man.
sp.p:
freedom, hey-day! hey-day, freedom! freedom,
hey-day,
freedom!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: O brave monster! Lead the way. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There be some sports are painful, and their labour
Delight in them sets off: some kinds of baseness
Are nobly undergone and most poor matters
Point to rich ends. This my mean task
Would be as heavy to me as odious, but
The mistress which I serve quickens what's dead
And makes my labours pleasures: O, she is
Ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed,
And he's composed of harshness. I must remove
Some thousands of these logs and pile them up,
Upon a sore injunction: my sweet mistress
Weeps when she sees me work, and says, such baseness
Had never like executor. I forget:
But these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labours,
Most busy lest, when I do it. Enter MIRANDA; and PROSPERO at a distance, unseen.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alas, now, pray you,
Work not so hard: I would the lightning had
Burnt up those logs that you are enjoin'd to pile!
Pray, set it down and rest you: when this burns,
'Twill weep for having wearied you. My father
Is hard at study; pray now, rest yourself;
He's safe for these three hours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O most dear mistress,
The sun will set before I shall discharge
What I must strive to do.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: If you'll sit down,
I'll bear your logs the while: pray, give me that;
I'll carry it to the pile.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, precious creature;
I had rather crack my sinews, break my back,
Than you should such dishonour undergo,
While I sit lazy by.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It would become me
As well as it does you: and I should do it
With much more ease; for my good will is to it.
And yours it is against.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Poor worm, thou art infected!
This visitation shows it.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You look wearily.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, noble mistress; 'tis fresh morning with me
When you are by at night. I do beseech you--
Chiefly that I might set it in my prayers--
What is your name?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Miranda.--O my father,
I have broke your hest to say so!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Admired Miranda!
Indeed the top of admiration! worth
What's dearest to the world! Full many a lady
I have eyed with best regard and many a time.
The harmony of their tongues hath into bondage
Brought my too diligent ear: for several virtues
Have I liked several women; never any
With so full soul, but some defect in her
Did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed
And put it to the foil: but you, O you,
So perfect and so peerless, are created
Of every creature's best!

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I do not know
One of my sex; no woman's face remember,
Save, from my glass, mine own; nor have I seen
More that I may call men than you, good friend,
And my dear father: how features are abroad
I am skilless of; but, by my modesty,
The jewel in my dower, I would not wish
Any companion in the world but you,
Nor can imagination form a shape,
Besides yourself, to like of. But I prattle
Something too wildly and my father's precepts
I therein do forget.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am in my condition
A prince, Miranda; I do think, a king;
I would, not so!--and would no more endure
This wooden slavery than to suffer
The flesh-fly blow my mouth. Hear my soul speak:
The very instant that I saw you, did
My heart fly to your service: there resides,
To make me slave to it; and for your sake
Am I this patient log-man.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound
And crown what I profess with kind event
If I speak true! if hollowly, invert
What best is boded me to mischief! I
Beyond all limit of what else i' the world
Do love, prize, honour you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am a fool
To weep at what I am glad of.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Fair encounter
Of two most rare affections! Heavens rain grace
On that which breeds between 'em!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wherefore weep you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: At mine unworthiness that dare not offer
What I desire to give, and much less take
What I shall die to want. But this is trifling;
And all the more it seeks to hide itself.
The bigger bulk it shows. Hence, bashful cunning!
And prompt me, plain and holy innocence
I am your wife, if you will marry me,
If not, I'll die your maid: to be your fellow
You may deny me; but I'll be your servant,
Whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My mistress, dearest;
And I thus humble ever.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My husband, then?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ay, with a heart as willing
As bondage e'er of freedom: here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And mine, with my heart in't: and now farewell
Till half an hour hence,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l:
A thousand thousand!
[Exeunt Fer. and Mir. severally.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: So glad of this as they I cannot be,
Who are surprised withal: but my rejoicing
At nothing can be more. I'll to my book.
For yet ere supper-time must I perform
Much business appertaining. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Tell not me; when the butt is out, we
will drink
water; not a drop before: therefore
bear up, and board
'em. Servant-monster,
drink to me.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Servant-monster! the folly of this
island! They
say there 's but five upon this
isle:we are three of them;
if th' other two
be brained like us, the state totters.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Drink, servant-monster, when I bid
thee: thy eyes
are almost set in thy head.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Where should they be set else? he
were a
brave monster indeed, if they were set
in his tail.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
My man-monster hath drown'd his
tongue in
sack: for my part, the sea cannot
drown me; I swam,
ere I could recover the
shore, five and thirty leagues
off and on. By
this light, thou shalt be my lieutenant,
monster,
or my standard.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Your lieutenant, if you list; he 's no
standard.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: We'll not run, Monsieur Monster.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Nor go neither; but you'll lie like
dogs and yet
say nothing neither.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Moon-calf, speak once in thy life, if
thou beest
a good moon-calf.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How does thy honour? Let me lick thy shoe.
I'll not serve him; he is not valiant.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Thou liest, most ignorant monster:
I am in case
to justle a constable. Why, thou
deboshed fish, thou,
was there ever man a
coward that hath drunk so much
sack as I
to-day? Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being
but half a fish and half a monster?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Lo, how he mocks me! wilt thou let
him, my
lord?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
'Lord' quoth he! That a monster
should be such
a natural!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Lo, lo, again! bite him to death, I
prithee.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your
head: if
you prove a mutineer,--the next tree!
The poor monster 's
my subject and he shall
not suffer indignity.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
I thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be
pleased
to hearken once again to the suit I
made to thee?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Marry, will I: kneel and repeat it;
I
will stand, and so shall Trinculo.
Enter ARIEL, invisible.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
As I told thee before, I am subject to
a tyrant,
a sorcerer, that by his cunning hath
cheated me
of the island.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
Thou liest, thou jesting monkey, thou:
I would my valiant master would destroy thee!
I do not lie.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Trinculo, if you trouble him any more
in's tale,
by this hand, I will supplant some
of your teeth.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: Why, I said nothing.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p:
I say, by sorcery he got this isle;
From me he got it. If thy greatness will
Revenge it on him,--for I know thou darest,
But this thing dare not,--

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: That's most certain.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Thou shalt be lord of it and I'll serve thee.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
How now shall this be compassed?
Canst thou bring me to the party?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Yea, yea, my lord: I'll yield him thee asleep,
Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Thou liest; thou canst not.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What a pied ninny's this! Thou scurvy patch
I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows
And take his bottle from him: when that's gone
He shall drink nought but brine; for I'll not show him
Where the quick freshes are.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Trinculo, run into no further danger:
interrupt the monster one word further, and,
by this
hand, I'll turn my mercy out o' doors
and make a
stock-fish of thee.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Why, what did I? I did nothing.
I'll
go farther off.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Didst thou not say he lied?

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Do I so? take thou that. [Beats Trin.]
As you like this, give me the lie another time.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
I did not give the lie. Out o' your
wits and
hearing too?
A pox o' your bottle!
this can sack and drinking do.
A murrain on
your monster, and the devil take your
fingers!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Now, forward with your tale. Prithee,
stand
farther off.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Beat him enough: after a little time
I'll beat him too.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Stand farther. Come, proceed.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why, as I told thee, 'tis a custom with him,
I' th' afternoon to sleep: there thou mayst brain him,
Having first seized his books, or with a log
Batter his skull, or paunch him with a stake,
Or cut his wezand with thy knife. Remember
First to possess his books; for without them
He's but a sot, as I am, nor hath not
One spirit to command: they all do hate him
As rootedly as I. Burn but his books.
He has brave utensils,--for so he calls them,--
Which, when he has a house, he'll deck withal.
And that most deeply to consider is
The beauty of his daughter; he himself
Calls her a nonpareil: I never saw a woman,
But only Sycorax my dam and she;
But she as far surpasseth Sycorax
As great'st does least.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Is it so brave a lass?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ay, lord; she will become thy bed, I warrant.
And bring thee forth brave brood.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Monster, I will kill this man: his
daughter and
I will be king and queen,--save
our graces!--and Trinculo
and thyself shall
be viceroys.
Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
Give me thy hand: I am sorry I beat
thee;
but, while thou livest, keep a good
tongue in thy head.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Within this half hour will he be asleep:
Wilt thou destroy him then?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ay, on mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: This will I tell my master.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thou makest me merry; I am full of pleasure:
Let us be jocund: will you troll the catch
You taught me but while-ere?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
At thy request, monster, I will do
reason,
any reason. Come on, Trinculo, let
us sing.
[Sings.

lg.l: Flout 'em and scout 'em
And scout 'em and flout 'em;
Thought is free.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l:
That 's not the tune.
[Ariel plays the tune on a tabor and pipe.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: What is this same?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
This is the tune of our catch, played
by the picture
of Nobody.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
If thou beest a man, show thyself in
thy likeness:
if thou beest a devil, take 't as
thou list.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: O, forgive me my sins!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
He that dies pays all debts: I defy
thee.
Mercy upon us!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: Art thou afeard?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: No, monster, not I.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises.
Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight and hurt not.
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments
Will hum about mine ears, and sometimes voices
That, if I then had waked after long sleep,
Will make me sleep again: and then, in dreaming,
The clouds methought would open and show riches
Ready to drop upon me, that, when I waked,
I cried to dream again.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
This will prove a brave kingdom to
me,
where I shall have my music for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: When Prospero is destroyed.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p:
That shall be by and by:
I remember
the story.

sp.speaker: Trin.
Ste.
Trin.
sp.p:
Wilt come?
I'll follow, Stephano. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III
div.stage:
Enter ALONSO, SEBASTIAN, ANTONIO, GONZALO,
ADRIAN, FRANCISCO, and others.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: By'r lakin, I can go no further, sir;
My old bones ache: here's a maze trod indeed
Through forth-rights and meanders! By your patience,
I needs must rest me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Old lord, I cannot blame thee,
Who am myself attach'd with weariness,
To the dulling of my spirits: sit down, and rest,
Even here I will put off my hope and keep it
No longer for my flatterer: he is drown'd
Whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks
Our frustrate search on land. Well, let him go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am right glad that he 's so out of hope.
Do not, for one repulse, forego the purpose
That you resolved to effect.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
The next advantage
Will we take throughly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it be to-night;
For, now they are oppress'd with travel, they
Will not, nor cannot, use such vigilance
As when they are fresh.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: I say, to-night: no more. [Solemn and strange music.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What harmony is this? My good friends, hark!

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.p:
Marvellous sweet music! Enter PROSPERO above, invisible. Enter several
strange Shapes, bringing in a banquet;
they dance about it with gentle actions of
salutation; and, inviting the King, &c., to
eat, they depart.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Give us kind keepers, heavens! What were these?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A living drollery. Now I will believe
That there are unicorns, that in Arabia
There is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix
At this hour reigning there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll believe both;
And what does else want credit, come to me,
And I'll be sworn 'tis true; travellers ne'er did lie,
Though fools at home condemn 'em.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: If in Naples
I should report this now, would they believe me?
If I should say, I saw such islanders--
For, certes, these are people of the island--
Who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet, note,
Their manners are more gentle-kind than of
Our human generation you shall find
Many, nay, almost any.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Honest lord,
Thou hast said well; for some of you there present
Are worse than devils.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I cannot too much muse
Such shapes, such gesture and such sound, expressing,
Although they want the use of tongue, a kind
Of excellent dumb discourse.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Praise in departing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: They vanish'd strangely.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No matter, since
They have left their viands behind; for we have stomachs.
Will 't please you taste of what is here?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Faith, sir, you need not fear. When we were boys,
Who would believe that there were mountaineers
Dew-lapp'd like bulls, whose throats had hanging at 'em
Wallets of flesh? or that there were such men
Whose heads stood in their breasts? which now we find
Each putter-out of five for one will bring us
Good warrant of.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I will stand to and feed,
Although my last: no matter, since I feel
The best is past. Brother, my lord the duke,

Stand to and do as we.
Thunder and lightning.Enter ARIEL, like a
harpy, claps
his wings upon the table;
and, with a quaint device, the
banquet vanishes.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: You are three men of sin, whom Destiny,
That hath to instrument this lower world
And what is in 't, the never-surfeited sea
Hath caused to belch up you; and on this island
Where man doth not inhabit; you 'mongst men
Being most unfit to live. I have made you mad;
And even with such-like valour men hang and drown
Their proper selves. Alon., Seb. &c. draw their swords.
You fools! I and my fellows
Are ministers of Fate: the elements,
Of whom your swords are temper'd, may as well
Wound the loud winds, or with bemock'd-at stabs
Kill the still-closing waters, as diminish
One dowle that's in my plume: my fellowministers
Are like invulnerable. If you could hurt,
Your swords are now too massy for your strengths
And will not be uplifted. But remember--
For that's my business to you--that you three
From Milan did supplant good Prospero;
Exposed unto the sea, which hath requit it,
Him and his innocent child: for which foul deed
The powers, delaying, not forgetting, have
Incensed the seas and shores, yea, all the creatures,
Against your peace. Thee of thy son, Alonso,
They have bereft; and do pronounce by me
Lingering perdition, worse than any death
Can be at once, shall step by step attend
You and your ways; whose wraths to guard you from--
Which here, in this most desolate isle, else falls
Upon your heads--is nothing but heart-sorrow

And a clear life ensuing.
He vanishes in thunder; then, to soft music.
Enter the
Shapes again, and dance, with
mocks and mows, and
carrying out the
table.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Bravely the figure of this harpy hast thou
Perform'd, my Ariel; a grace it had, devouring:
Of my instruction hast thou nothing bated
In what thou hadst to say: so, with good life
And observation strange, my meaner ministers
Their several kinds have done. My high charms work
And these mine enemies are all knit up
In their distractions; they now are in my power;
And in these fits I leave them, while I visit
Young Ferdinand, whom they suppose is drown'd,
And his and mine loved darling. Exit above.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I' the name of something holy, sir, why stand you
In this strange stare?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: O, it is monstrous, monstrous!
Methought. the billows spoke and told me of it;
The winds did sing it to me, and the thunder,
That deep and dreadful organ-pipe, pronounced
The name of Prosper: it did bass my trespass.
Therefore my son i' the ooze is bedded, and
I'll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded
And with him there lie mudded. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: But one fiend at a time,
I'll fight their legions o'er.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll be thy second. [Exeunt Seb. and Ant.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: All three of them are desperate: their great guilt,
Like poison given to work a great time after,
Now 'gins to bite the spirits. I do beseech you
That are of suppler joints, follow them swiftly
And hinder them from what this ecstasy
May now provoke them to.

sp.speaker: Adr.
sp.l: Follow, I pray you. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: If I have too austerely punish'd you,
Your compensation makes amends, for I
Have given you here a thrid of mine own life,
Or that for which I live; who once again
I tender to thy hand: all thy vexations
Were but my trials of thy love, and thou
Hast strangely stood the test: here, afore Heaven,
I ratify this my rich gift. O Ferdinand,
Do not smile at me that I boast her off,
For thou shalt find she will outstrip all praise
And make it halt behind her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I do believe it
Against an oracle.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Then, as my gift and thine own acquisition
Worthily purchased, take my daughter: but
If thou dost break her virgin-knot before
All sanctimonious ceremonies may
With full and holy rite be minister'd,
No sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall
To make this contract grow; but barren hate,
Sour-eyed disdain and discord shall bestrew
The union of your bed with weeds so loathly
That you shall hate it both: therefore take heed,
As Hymen's lamps shall light you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: As I hope
For quiet days, fair issue and long life,
With such love as 'tis now, the murkiest den,
The most opportune place, the strong'st suggestion
Our worser genius can, shall never melt
Mine honour into lust, to take away
The edge of that day's celebration
When I shall think, or Phoebus' steeds are founder'd,
Or Night kept chain'd below.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Fairly spoke.
Sit then and talk with her; she is thine own.
What, Ariel! my industrious servant, Ariel! Enter ARIEL.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: What would my potent master? here I am.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service
Did worthily perform; and I must use you
In such another trick. Go bring the rabble,
O'er whom I give thee power, here to this place:
Incite them to quick motion; for I must
Bestow upon the eyes of this young couple
Some vanity of mine art: it is my promise,
And they expect it from me.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Presently!

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Ay, with a twink.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Before you can say 'come' and 'go,'
And breathe twice and cry 'so, so,'
Each one, tripping on his toe,
Will be here with mop and mow.
Do you love me, master? no?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Dearly, my delicate Ariel. Do not approach
Till thou dost hear me call.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.l: Well, I conceive. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Look thou be true; do not give dalliance
Too much the rein: the strongest oaths are straw
To the fire i' the blood: be more abstemious,
Or else, good night your vow!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I warrant you, sir;
The white cold virgin snow upon my heart
Abates the ardour of my liver.

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Well.
Now come, my Ariel! bring a corollary,
Rather than want a spirit: appear, and pertly!

No tongue! all eyes! be silent. [Soft music.
Enter IRIS.

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.l: Ceres, most bounteous lady, thy rich leas
Of wheat, rye, barley, vetches, oats and pease;
Thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep,
And flat meads thatch'd with stover, them to keep;
Thy banks with pioned and twilled brims,
Which spongy April at thy hest betrims,
To make cold nymphs chaste crowns; and thy broom-groves,
Whose shadow the dismissed bachelor loves,
Being lass-lorn; thy pole-clipt vineyard;
And thy sea-marge, sterile and rocky-hard,
Where thou thyself dost air;--the queen o' the sky,
Whose watery arch and messenger am I,
Bids thee leave these, and with her sovereign grace,
Here on this grass-plot, in this very place,
To come and sport: her peacocks fly amain:

Approach, rich Ceres, her to entertain.
Enter CERES.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Hail, many-colour'd messenger, that ne'er
Dost disobey the wife of Jupiter;
Who with thy saffron wings upon my flowers
Diffusest honey-drops, refreshing showers,
And with each end of thy blue bow dost crown
My bosky acres and my unshrubb'd down,
Rich scaff to my proud earth; why hath thy queen
Summon'd me hither, to this short-grass'd green?

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.l: A contract of true love to celebrate;
And some donation freely to estate
On the blest lovers.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: Tell me, heavenly bow,
If Venus or her son, as thou dost know,
Do now attend the queen? Since they did plot
The means that dusky Dis my daughter got,
Her and her blind boy's scandal'd company
I have forsworn.

sp.speaker: Iris.
sp.l: Of her society
Be not afraid: I met her deity
Cutting the clouds towards Paphos and her son
Dove-drawn with her. Here thought they to have done
Some wanton charm upon this man and maid,
Whose vows are, that no bed-right shall be paid
Till Hymen's torch be lighted: but in vain;
Mars's hot minion is return'd again;
Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows,
Swears he will shoot no more but play with sparrows
And be a boy right out.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.l: High'st queen of state.
Great Juno, comes: I know her by her gait. Enter JUNO.

sp.speaker: Juno.
sp.l: How does my bounteous sister? Go with me
To bless this twain, that they may prosperous be
And honour'd in their issue. They sing:

lg.l: Honour, riches, marriage-blessing,
Long continuance, and increasing,
Hourly joys be still upon you
Juno sings her blessings on you.
Earth's increase, foison plenty,
Barns and garners never empty,
Vines with clustering bunches growing,
Plants with goodly burthen bowing;
Spring come to you at the farthest
In the very end of harvest!
Scarcity and want shall shun you;
Ceres' blessing so is on you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This is a most majestic vision, and
Harmonious charmingly. May I be bold
To think these spirits?

sp.speaker: Pros.
sp.l: Spirits, which by mine art
I have from their confines call'd to enact
My present fancies.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let me live here ever;
So rare a wonder'd father and a wife

Makes this place Paradise.
[Juno and Ceres whisper, and send
Iris on employment.
